title: Conservative impl trait + named lifetimes gives access to invalid memory.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
I've just noticed a really unsound behavior with the latest nightly rustc (might have been present before).

Despite several hours of trying, I've not yet found a way to reproduce on a minimal example, because it took several layers of "Handler traits" (I'm writing a server) with methods that call functions returning `impl Future<…>` (conservative impl trait).

Still, I thought this was worth reporting because I've been given access to dropped memory, and that scared me.

Basically, I had a buffer (a `Vec<u8>`), and I managed to give a borrow on that buffer, to a deeply nested closure (using futures/tokio). My understanding of the problem is that Tokio returns immediately (because some IO blocks), the buffer gets deallocated, but the borrow is still accessible from the closure on the next `poll()`.

On most smaller examples I've tried, Rust prevents me from doing this, but the error locations are (rightfully) in the closure.

My server then calls `debug!` on that buffer, and prints parts of the buffer, overwritten by subsequent writes.

In my case, this could not happen when I started threading the `Request` buffer through the closures, and have my server return `(Request, Response)` (I needed the `Request` anyway), instead of just `Response`.
